column2: Chapter VIII.

column2: Mitya bustled about.
column3: Mitya bustled about.

column2: All sorts of people began coming into the room to look on, peasants and their women, who had been roused from sleep and attracted by the hopes of another marvelous entertainment such as they had enjoyed a month before.
column3: All sorts of people began coming into the room to look on, peasants and their women, who had been roused from sleep and attracted by the hopes of another marvelous entertainment such as they had enjoyed a month before.

column2: He uncorked bottles and poured out wine for every one who presented himself.

column3: Only the girls were very eager for the champagne.

column2: The men preferred rum, brandy, and, above all, hot punch.
column3: The men preferred rum, brandy, and, above all, hot punch.

column3: Mitya had chocolate made for all the girls, and ordered that three samovars should be kept boiling all night to provide tea and punch for everyone to help himself.

column2: An absurd chaotic confusion followed, but Mitya was in his natural element, and the more foolish it became, the more his spirits rose.
column3: An absurd chaotic confusion followed, but Mitya was in his natural element, and the more foolish it became, the more his spirits rose.

column2: This was probably why the landlord, Trifon Borissovitch, kept hovering about Mitya to protect him. He seemed to have given up all idea of going to bed that night; but he drank little, only one glass of punch, and kept a sharp look-out on Mitya's interests after his own fashion.
column3: This was probably why the landlord, Trifon Borissovitch, kept hovering about Mitya to protect him. He seemed to have given up all idea of going to bed that night; but he drank little, only one glass of punch, and kept a sharp look out on Mitya's interests after his own fashion.

column3: He intervened in the nick of time, civilly and obsequiously persuading Mitya not to give away "cigars and Rhine wine," and, above all, money to the peasants as he had done before.

column3: Mitya remembered Andrey again, and ordered punch to be sent out to him.

column2: So you meant to shoot yourself to-morrow!
column3: So you meant to shoot yourself to morrow!

column3: What for?

column2: I like such reckless fellows as you," she lisped, with a rather halting tongue.
column3: I like such reckless fellows as you," she lisped, with a rather halting tongue.

column2: So you would go any length for me, eh?	So you would go any length for me, eh?

column3: Did you really mean to shoot yourself to morrow, you stupid?

column2: To-morrow I may have something to say to you....
column3: To morrow I may have something to say to you....

column3: I won't say it to day, but to morrow.

column2: You'd like it to be to-day? No, I don't want to to-day.

column3: Once, however, she called him, as it were, puzzled and uneasy.

column3: I see you're sad....

column3: Yes, I see it," she added, looking intently into his eyes.

No, be merry.

column2: I'm merry; you be merry, too.... I love somebody here.

column3: Then a gypsy comes along and he, too, tries:

column3: The gypsy came to try the girls: Would they love him, would they not?

column3: But they couldn't love the gypsy either:

column2: He would be a thief, I fear, And would cause me many a tear.

column2: The soldier came to try the girls: Would they love him, would they not?

column2: The merchant came to try the girls: Would they love him, would they not?
column3: The merchant came to try the girls: Would they love him, would they not?

column3: And it appears that he wins their love because:

column2: That's just a song of yesterday, he said aloud.
column3: That's just a song of yesterday, he said aloud.

column2: Who writes such things for them?	Who writes such things for them?

column2: All right, all right....

column3: Mitya's head was burning.

column2: He went outside to the wooden balcony which ran round the whole building on the inner side, overlooking the courtyard.
column3: He went outside to the wooden balcony which ran round the whole building on the inner side, overlooking the courtyard.

column2: The fresh air revived him.
column3: The fresh air revived him.

column2: He stood alone in a dark corner, and suddenly clutched his head in both hands.
column3: He stood alone in a dark corner, and suddenly clutched his head in both hands.

column2: His scattered thoughts came together; his sensations blended into a whole and threw a sudden light into his mind.
column3: His scattered thoughts came together; his sensations blended into a whole and threw a sudden light into his mind.

column2: A fearful and terrible light!
column3: A fearful and terrible light!

column2: If I'm to shoot myself, why not now? passed through his mind.
column3: If I'm to shoot myself, why not now? passed through his mind.

column2: Why not go for the pistols, bring them here, and here, in this dark dirty corner, make an end? Almost a minute he stood, undecided.
column3: Why not go for the pistols, bring them here, and here, in this dark dirty corner, make an end? Almost a minute he stood, undecided.

column3: But yet it was easier for him then.

column2: But now?
column3: But now?

column2: Was it the same as then?
column3: Was it the same as then?

column2: Now one phantom, one terror at least was at an end: that first, rightful lover, that fateful figure had vanished, leaving no trace.

column2: It would never return.
column3: It would never return.

column2: She was ashamed, and from her eyes he could see now whom she loved.
column3: She was ashamed, and from her eyes he could see now whom she loved.

column2: Now he had everything to make life happy ... but he could not go on living, he could not; oh, damnation!
column3: Now he had everything to make life happy ... but he could not go on living, he could not; oh, damnation!

column2: Lord, thou hast wrought miracles for such sinners as me!
column3: Lord, thou hast wrought miracles for such sinners as me!

column3: But what, what if the old man's alive?

column3: He jumped up and ran back to the room-to her, to her, his queen for ever!

column3: Was not one moment of her love worth all the rest of life, even in the agonies of disgrace?

column2: She was sitting in the corner, on a trunk.
column3: She was sitting in the corner, on a trunk.

column3: Bent forward, with her head and arms on the bed close by, she was crying bitterly, doing her utmost to stifle her sobs that she might not be heard.

column3: Seeing Mitya, she beckoned him to her, and when he ran to her, she grasped his hand tightly.

column2: And now, O Lord, it's not the same man.
column3: And now, O Lord, it's not the same man.

column2: Even his face is not the same; he's different altogether.
column3: Even his face is not the same; he's different altogether.

column2: I'll be your slave now, your slave for the rest of my life.
column3: I'll be your slave now, your slave for the rest of my life.

column2: It's sweet to be a slave. Kiss me!
column3: It's sweet to be a slave. Kiss me!

column2: Beat me, ill-treat me, do what you will with me....
column3: Beat me, ill treat me, do what you will with me....

column2: And I do deserve to suffer.
column3: And I do deserve to suffer.

column2: Stay, wait, afterwards, I won't have that...." she suddenly thrust him away.
column3: Stay, wait, afterwards, I won't have that...." she suddenly thrust him away.

column2: Mitya followed like a drunken man.
column3: Mitya followed like a drunken man.

column2: Yes, come what may--whatever may happen now, for one minute I'd give the whole world, he thought.
column3: Yes, come what may-whatever may happen now, for one minute I'd give the whole world, he thought.

column2: Grushenka did, in fact, toss off a whole glass of champagne at one gulp, and became at once very tipsy.
column3: Grushenka did, in fact, toss off a whole glass of champagne at one gulp, and became at once very tipsy.

column2: She sat down in the same chair as before, with a blissful smile on her face.
column3: She sat down in the same chair as before, with a blissful smile on her face.

column2: Even Kalganov felt a stir at the heart and went up to her.
column3: Even Kalganov felt a stir at the heart and went up to her.

column2: Did you feel how I kissed you when you were asleep just now? she said thickly.
column3: Did you feel how I kissed you when you were asleep just now? she said thickly.

column2: I'm drunk now, that's what it is....	I'm drunk now, that's what it is....
And aren't you drunk?
column3: And aren't you drunk?

column2: And why isn't Mitya drinking?
column3: And why isn't Mitya drinking?

column2: Why don't you drink, Mitya?
column3: Why don't you drink, Mitya?

column2: I'm drunk, and you don't drink...."
column3: I'm drunk, and you don't drink...."

column2: I am drunk!	I am drunk!
He drank off another glass, and--he thought it strange himself--that glass made him completely drunk.
column3: He drank off another glass, and-he thought it strange himself-that glass made him completely drunk.

column2: He was suddenly drunk, although till that moment he had been quite sober, he remembered that.
column3: He was suddenly drunk, although till that moment he had been quite sober, he remembered that.

column2: From that moment everything whirled about him, as though he were delirious.
column3: From that moment everything whirled about him, as though he were delirious.

column2: He walked, laughed, talked to everybody, without knowing what he was doing.
column3: He walked, laughed, talked to everybody, without knowing what he was doing.

column2: Only one persistent burning sensation made itself felt continually, "like a red-hot coal in his heart," he said afterwards.
column3: Only one persistent burning sensation made itself felt continually, "like a red hot coal in his heart," he said afterwards.

column2: He went up to her, sat beside her, gazed at her, listened to her....
column3: He went up to her, sat beside her, gazed at her, listened to her....

column2: When the girl came up, she either kissed her, or made the sign of the cross over her.
column3: When the girl came up, she either kissed her, or made the sign of the cross over her.

column2: She was greatly amused by the "little old man," as she called Maximov.
column3: She was greatly amused by the "little old man," as she called Maximov.

column2: He ran up every minute to kiss her hands, "each little finger," and finally he danced another dance to an old song, which he sang himself.
column3: He ran up every minute to kiss her hands, "each little finger," and finally he danced another dance to an old song, which he sang himself.

column2: He danced with special vigor to the refrain:
column3: He danced with special vigor to the refrain:

column2: Give him something, Mitya, said Grushenka.
column3: Give him something, Mitya, said Grushenka.

column2: Give him a present, he's poor, you know.	Give him a present, he's poor, you know.
Ah, the poor, the insulted!...
column3: Ah, the poor, the insulted!...

column2: Do you know, Mitya, I shall go into a nunnery.
column3: Do you know, Mitya, I shall go into a nunnery.

column2: But to-day let us dance.
column3: But to day let us dance.

column2: To-morrow to the nunnery, but to-day we'll dance.
column3: To morrow to the nunnery, but to day we'll dance.

column2: I want to play to-day, good people, and what of it?
column3: I want to play to day, good people, and what of it?

column2: God will forgive us.
column3: God will forgive us.

column2: I gave a little onion.
column3: I gave a little onion.

column2: Wicked as I've been, I want to pray.
column3: Wicked as I've been, I want to pray.

column2: Mitya, let them dance, don't stop them.
column3: Mitya, let them dance, don't stop them.

column2: Every one in the world is good.
column3: Every one in the world is good.

column2: Every one--even the worst of them.
column3: Every one-even the worst of them.

column2: The world's a nice place.
column3: The world's a nice place.

column2: You know I am good.
column3: You know I am good.

column2: I'm very good....
column3: I'm very good....

column2: Come, why am I so good?"
column3: Come, why am I so good?"

column2: So Grushenka babbled on, getting more and more drunk.
column3: So Grushenka babbled on, getting more and more drunk.

column2: She got up from her chair, staggering.
column3: She got up from her chair, staggering.

column2: Mitya, don't give me any more wine--if I ask you, don't give it to me.	Mitya, don't give me any more wine-if I ask you, don't give it to me.
Wine doesn't give peace.
column3: Wine doesn't give peace.

column2: I want to dance.
column3: I want to dance.

column2: Let every one see how I dance ... let them see how beautifully I dance...."
column3: Let every one see how I dance ... let them see how beautifully I dance...."

column2: She really meant it.
column3: She really meant it.

column2: She pulled a white cambric handkerchief out of her pocket, and took it by one corner in her right hand, to wave it in the dance.
column3: She pulled a white cambric handkerchief out of her pocket, and took it by one corner in her right hand, to wave it in the dance.

column2: Mitya ran to and fro, the girls were quiet, and got ready to break into a dancing song at the first signal.
column3: Mitya ran to and fro, the girls were quiet, and got ready to break into a dancing song at the first signal.

column2: Maximov, hearing that Grushenka wanted to dance, squealed with delight, and ran skipping about in front of her, humming:
column3: Maximov, hearing that Grushenka wanted to dance, squealed with delight, and ran skipping about in front of her, humming:

column2: Mitya, why don't they come?
column3: Mitya, why don't they come?

column2: Let every one come ... to look on.
column3: Let every one come ... to look on.

column2: Call them in, too, that were locked in....
column3: Call them in, too, that were locked in....

column2: Why did you lock them in?
column3: Why did you lock them in?

column2: Tell them I'm going to dance.
column3: Tell them I'm going to dance.

column2: Let them look on, too...."
column3: Let them look on, too...."

column2: Mitya walked with a drunken swagger to the locked door, and began knocking to the Poles with his fist.
column3: Mitya walked with a drunken swagger to the locked door, and began knocking to the Poles with his fist.

column2: Come, she's going to dance.
column3: Come, she's going to dance.

column2: She calls you."
column3: She calls you."

column2: You're a little scoundrel, that's what you are."
column3: You're a little scoundrel, that's what you are."

column2: He too was drunk.
column3: He too was drunk.

column2: Be quiet, boy!	Be quiet, boy!
If I call him a scoundrel, it doesn't mean that I called all Poland so.
column3: If I call him a scoundrel, it doesn't mean that I called all Poland so.

column2: Be quiet, my pretty boy, eat a sweetmeat."
column3: Be quiet, my pretty boy, eat a sweetmeat."

column2: As though they were not men.
column3: As though they were not men.

column2: Why won't they make friends?" said Grushenka, and went forward to dance.
column3: Why won't they make friends?" said Grushenka, and went forward to dance.

column2: The chorus broke into "Ah, my porch, my new porch!" Grushenka flung back her head, half opened her lips, smiled, waved her handkerchief, and suddenly, with a violent lurch, stood still in the middle of the room, looking bewildered.
column3: The chorus broke into "Ah, my porch, my new porch!" Grushenka flung back her head, half opened her lips, smiled, waved her handkerchief, and suddenly, with a violent lurch, stood still in the middle of the room, looking bewildered.

column2: I'm weak.... she said in an exhausted voice.
column3: I'm weak.... she said in an exhausted voice.

column2: Forgive me....	Forgive me....
I'm weak, I can't....
column3: I'm weak, I can't....

column2: I'm sorry."
column3: I'm sorry."

column2: She bowed to the chorus, and then began bowing in all directions.
column3: She bowed to the chorus, and then began bowing in all directions.

column2: I'm sorry....	I'm sorry....
Forgive me...."
column3: Forgive me...."

column2: The lady's been drinking.	The lady's been drinking.
The pretty lady has been drinking," voices were heard saying.
column3: The pretty lady has been drinking," voices were heard saying.

column2: The lady's drunk too much, Maximov explained to the girls, giggling.
column3: The lady's drunk too much, Maximov explained to the girls, giggling.

column2: Mitya, lead me away ... take me, said Grushenka helplessly.
column3: Mitya, lead me away ... take me, said Grushenka helplessly.

column2: Mitya pounced on her, snatched her up in his arms, and carried the precious burden through the curtains.
column3: Mitya pounced on her, snatched her up in his arms, and carried the precious burden through the curtains.

column2: Well, now I'll go, thought Kalganov, and walking out of the blue room, he closed the two halves of the door after him.
column3: Well, now I'll go, thought Kalganov, and walking out of the blue room, he closed the two halves of the door after him.

column2: Mitya laid Grushenka on the bed and kissed her on the lips.
column3: Mitya laid Grushenka on the bed and kissed her on the lips.

column2: Don't touch me.... she faltered, in an imploring voice.
column3: Don't touch me.... she faltered, in an imploring voice.

column2: Don't touch me, till I'm yours....	Don't touch me, till I'm yours....
I've told you I'm yours, but don't touch me ... spare me....
column3: I've told you I'm yours, but don't touch me ... spare me....

column2: With them here, with them close, you mustn't.
column3: With them here, with them close, you mustn't.

column2: He's here.
column3: He's here.

column2: It's nasty here...."
column3: It's nasty here...."

column2: I'll obey you!	I'll obey you!
I won't think of it ...
column3: I won't think of it ...

column2: I worship you!" muttered Mitya. "Yes, it's nasty here, it's abominable."
column3: I worship you!" muttered Mitya. "Yes, it's nasty here, it's abominable."

column2: I know, though you're a brute, you're generous, Grushenka articulated with difficulty.
column3: I know, though you're a brute, you're generous, Grushenka articulated with difficulty.

column2: It must be honorable ... it shall be honorable for the future ... and let us be honest, let us be good, not brutes, but good ... take me away, take me far away, do you hear?	It must be honorable ... it shall be honorable for the future ... and let us be honest, let us be good, not brutes, but good ... take me away, take me far away, do you hear?
I don't want it to be here, but far, far away...."
column3: I don't want it to be here, but far, far away...."

column2: Oh, yes, yes, it must be! said Mitya, pressing her in his arms.
column3: Oh, yes, yes, it must be! said Mitya, pressing her in his arms.

column2: I'll take you and we'll fly away....	I'll take you and we'll fly away....
Oh, I'd give my whole life for one year only to know about that blood!"
column3: Oh, I'd give my whole life for one year only to know about that blood!"

column2: What blood? asked Grushenka, bewildered.
column3: What blood? asked Grushenka, bewildered.

column2: Nothing, muttered Mitya, through his teeth.
column3: Nothing, muttered Mitya, through his teeth.

column2: Grusha, you wanted to be honest, but I'm a thief.	Grusha, you wanted to be honest, but I'm a thief.
But I've stolen money from Katya....
column3: But I've stolen money from Katya....

column2: From Katya, from that young lady?	From Katya, from that young lady?
No, you didn't steal it.
column3: No, you didn't steal it.

column2: Why make a fuss?
column3: Why make a fuss?

column2: Now everything of mine is yours.
column3: Now everything of mine is yours.

column2: What does money matter?
column3: What does money matter?

column2: We shall waste it anyway....
column3: We shall waste it anyway....

column2: Folks like us are bound to waste money.
column3: Folks like us are bound to waste money.

column2: But we'd better go and work the land.
column3: But we'd better go and work the land.

column2: I want to dig the earth with my own hands.
column3: I want to dig the earth with my own hands.

column2: We must work, do you hear?
column3: We must work, do you hear?

column2: I won't be your mistress, I'll be faithful to you, I'll be your slave, I'll work for you.
column3: I won't be your mistress, I'll be faithful to you, I'll be your slave, I'll work for you.

column2: We'll go to the young lady and bow down to her together, so that she may forgive us, and then we'll go away.
column3: We'll go to the young lady and bow down to her together, so that she may forgive us, and then we'll go away.

column2: And if she won't forgive us, we'll go, anyway.
column3: And if she won't forgive us, we'll go, anyway.

column2: Don't love her any more.
column3: Don't love her any more.

column2: If you love her, I shall strangle her....
column3: If you love her, I shall strangle her....

column2: I'll put out both her eyes with a needle...."
column3: I'll put out both her eyes with a needle...."

column2: I love you.	I love you.
I love only you.
column3: I love only you.

column2: Why Siberia?	Why Siberia?
I don't care ... we'll work ... there's snow in Siberia....
column3: I don't care ... we'll work ... there's snow in Siberia....

column2: I love driving in the snow ... and must have bells....
column3: I love driving in the snow ... and must have bells....

column2: Do you hear, there's a bell ringing?
column3: Do you hear, there's a bell ringing?

column2: Where is that bell ringing?
column3: Where is that bell ringing?

column2: There are people coming....
column3: There are people coming....

column2: Now it's stopped."
column3: Now it's stopped."

column2: Mitya let his head sink on her breast.
column3: Mitya let his head sink on her breast.

column2: Grushenka opened her eyes.
column3: Grushenka opened her eyes.

column2: What's the matter?	What's the matter?
Yes ... a bell ...
column3: Yes ... a bell ...

column2: I've been asleep and dreamt I was driving over the snow with bells, and I dozed.
column3: I've been asleep and dreamt I was driving over the snow with bells, and I dozed.

column2: And far, far away.
column3: And far, far away.

column2: Close to you, murmured Mitya, kissing her dress, her bosom, her hands. And suddenly he had a strange fancy: it seemed to him that she was looking straight before her, not at him, not into his face, but over his head, with an intent, almost uncanny fixity.
column3: Close to you, murmured Mitya, kissing her dress, her bosom, her hands. And suddenly he had a strange fancy: it seemed to him that she was looking straight before her, not at him, not into his face, but over his head, with an intent, almost uncanny fixity.

column2: An expression of wonder, almost of alarm, came suddenly into her face.
column3: An expression of wonder, almost of alarm, came suddenly into her face.

column2: Mitya turned, and saw that some one had, in fact, parted the curtains and seemed to be watching them.
column3: Mitya turned, and saw that some one had, in fact, parted the curtains and seemed to be watching them.

column2: And not one person alone, it seemed.
column3: And not one person alone, it seemed.

column2: He jumped up and walked quickly to the intruder.
column3: He jumped up and walked quickly to the intruder.

column2: Here, come to us, come here, said a voice, speaking not loudly, but firmly and peremptorily.
column3: Here, come to us, come here, said a voice, speaking not loudly, but firmly and peremptorily.

column2: Mitya passed to the other side of the curtain and stood stock still.
column3: Mitya passed to the other side of the curtain and stood stock still.

column2: The room was filled with people, but not those who had been there before.
column3: The room was filled with people, but not those who had been there before.

column2: He recognized all those people instantly.
column3: He recognized all those people instantly.

column2: And that "consumptive-looking" trim dandy, "who always has such polished boots"--that was the deputy prosecutor.
column3: And that "consumptive looking" trim dandy, "who always has such polished boots"--that was the deputy prosecutor.

column2: He has a chronometer worth four hundred roubles; he showed it to me. And that small young man in spectacles....
column3: He has a chronometer worth four hundred roubles; he showed it to me. And that small young man in spectacles....

column2: And this man--the inspector of police, Mavriky Mavrikyevitch, a man he knew well.
column3: And this man-the inspector of police, Mavriky Mavrikyevitch, a man he knew well.

column2: And those fellows with the brass plates on, why are they here?
column3: And those fellows with the brass plates on, why are they here?

column2: And those other two ... peasants.... And there at the door Kalganov with Trifon Borissovitch....
column3: And those other two ... peasants.... And there at the door Kalganov with Trifon Borissovitch....

column2: Gentlemen!	Gentlemen!
What's this for, gentlemen?" began Mitya, but suddenly, as though beside himself, not knowing what he was doing, he cried aloud, at the top of his voice:
column3: What's this for, gentlemen?" began Mitya, but suddenly, as though beside himself, not knowing what he was doing, he cried aloud, at the top of his voice:

column2: The young man in spectacles moved forward suddenly, and stepping up to Mitya, began with dignity, though hurriedly:
column3: The young man in spectacles moved forward suddenly, and stepping up to Mitya, began with dignity, though hurriedly:

column2: We have to make ... in brief, I beg you to come this way, this way to the sofa....	We have to make ... in brief, I beg you to come this way, this way to the sofa....
The old man! cried Mitya frantically.
column3: The old man! cried Mitya frantically.

column2: And he sank, almost fell, on a chair close by, as though he had been mown down by a scythe.
column3: And he sank, almost fell, on a chair close by, as though he had been mown down by a scythe.

column2: You understand?	You understand?
Monster and parricide!
column3: Monster and parricide!

column2: Your father's blood cries out against you!" the old captain of police roared suddenly, stepping up to Mitya.
column3: Your father's blood cries out against you!" the old captain of police roared suddenly, stepping up to Mitya.

column2: He was beside himself, crimson in the face and quivering all over.
column3: He was beside himself, crimson in the face and quivering all over.

column2: This is impossible! cried the small young man.
column3: This is impossible! cried the small young man.

column2: Mihail Makarovitch, Mihail Makarovitch, this won't do!...	Mihail Makarovitch, Mihail Makarovitch, this won't do!...
I beg you'll allow me to speak.
column3: I beg you'll allow me to speak.

column2: This is delirium, gentlemen, raving delirium, cried the captain of police; "look at him: drunk, at this time of night, in the company of a disreputable woman, with the blood of his father on his hands....
column3: This is delirium, gentlemen, raving delirium, cried the captain of police; "look at him: drunk, at this time of night, in the company of a disreputable woman, with the blood of his father on his hands....

column2: I beg you most earnestly, dear Mihail Makarovitch, to restrain your feelings, the prosecutor said in a rapid whisper to the old police captain, "or I shall be forced to resort to--"
column3: I beg you most earnestly, dear Mihail Makarovitch, to restrain your feelings, the prosecutor said in a rapid whisper to the old police captain, "or I shall be forced to resort to-"

column2: But the little lawyer did not allow him to finish.
column3: But the little lawyer did not allow him to finish.

column2: He turned to Mitya, and delivered himself in a loud, firm, dignified voice:
column3: He turned to Mitya, and delivered himself in a loud, firm, dignified voice:
